Fuel leak - I suppose this means hydrogen.  Hydrogen leaks out of any tank with the slightest imperfection, even when other gases won't leak out. Hydrogen is colorless and odorless, it leaks easily, and when it burns you often can't see the flame in daylight.  It explodes (think Hindenburg) too.  What could go wrong?

SpaceX has a continuous assembly line cranking out boosters and spaceships.  They then continuously test by trying to fly them.  If one fails, next one up.  If not needed, they scrap them.  Failure is built into their plans as are modifications to the rocket itself.

NASA and the traditional industry plans on completing a final design, building one rocket, and getting it right the one time.  So they have to hope the original plan was correct and then test the heck out of everything.  If it fails, they have no backup.  They tried to skip tests on the SLS.  That is now coming back to bite them.

NASA's way is the traditional way.  It is not new, it is not woke.  It is why our space progress has been so slow.  SpaceX's philosophy is new.  It is now being used by Rocket Lab and other startups.  But NASA had too much sunk into the old way to change.

Plus, Congress.  Congress gives NASA the money.  Senators like having NASA bujild or source parts from their state.  This again is inefficient.

If the U.S. Senate had not mandated using Shuttle parts on SLS, NASA would have gone to LOX/Kerosene like they used on Saturn for the first stage.  Much easier to work with, and to seal.  Shuttle used hydrogen, which fit that vehicle design better, but with an inline rocket design, there was no need to use hydrogen.  Hydrogen adds much more cost and complexity in seals, valves, engine turbo pumps, propellant lines.  The U.S. Senate wanted to keep the old Shuttle supply lines running.
